literals: '<textarea tabindex="-1" style="position:absolute; top:-999px; left:0; right:auto; bottom:auto; border:0; padding: 0; -moz-box-sizing:content-box; -webkit-box-sizing:content-box; box-sizing:content-box; word-wrap:break-word; height:0 !important; min-height:0 !important; overflow:hidden; transition:none; -webkit-transition:none; -moz-transition:none;"/>'
comments:
!
     Autosize v1.18.1 - 2013-11-05
     Automatically adjust textarea height based on user input.
     (c) 2013 Jack Moore - http://www.jacklmoore.com/autosize
     license: http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php
border:0 is unnecessary, but avoids a bug in Firefox on OSX
line-height is conditionally included because IE7/IE8/old Opera do not return the correct value.
to keep track which textarea is being mirrored when adjust() is called.
the mirror element, which is used to calculate what size the mirrored element should be.
test that line-height can be accurately copied.
exit if autosize has already been applied, or if the textarea is the mirror element.
IE8 and lower return 'auto', which parses to NaN, if no min-height is set.
horizontal overflow is hidden, so break-word is necessary for handling words longer than the textarea width
The mirror width must exactly match the textarea width, so using getBoundingClientRect because it doesn't round the sub-pixel value.
window.getComputedStyle, getBoundingClientRect returning a width are unsupported and unneeded in IE8 and lower.
mirror is a duplicate textarea located off-screen that
is automatically updated to contain the same text as the
original textarea.  mirror always has a height of 0.
This gives a cross-browser supported way getting the actual
height of the text, through the scrollTop property.
Chrome-specific fix:
When the textarea y-overflow is hidden, Chrome doesn't reflow the text to account for the space
made available by removing the scrollbar. This workaround triggers the reflow for Chrome.
Using mainly bare JS in this function because it is going
to fire very often while typing, and needs to very efficient.
Setting scrollTop to zero is needed in IE8 and lower for the next step to be accurately applied
Using scrollTop rather than scrollHeight because scrollHeight is non-standard and includes padding.
Detects IE9.  IE9 does not fire onpropertychange or oninput for deletions,
so binding to onkeyup to catch most of those occasions.  There is no way that I
know of to detect something like 'cut' in IE9.
IE7 / IE8
Modern Browsers
Set options.resizeDelay to false if using fixed-width textarea elements.
Uses a timeout and width check to reduce the amount of times adjust needs to be called after window resize.
Event for manual triggering if needed.
Should only be needed when the value of the textarea is changed through JavaScript rather than user input.
Event for manual triggering that also forces the styles to update as well.
Should only be needed if one of typography styles of the textarea change, and the textarea is already the target of the adjust method.
Call adjust in case the textarea already contains text.
jQuery or jQuery-like library, such as Zepto
